body:
Note for triage: it's unfortunate that this prevents the collection from being serialized, at least in System.Text.Json. We should consider adding the setter back because of this.

@giarico You can [customize the T4 template](https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/ef/core/managing-schemas/scaffolding/templates?tabs=dotnet-core-cli) to create setters.
Thanks, @ajcvickers - I will add this as default in the next version of the templates supplied with EF Core Power Tools

issue.title: Setter removed from Entity for Child Entities in EF 7

repository.name: EFCorePowerTools
repository.description: Entity Framework Core Power Tools - reverse engineering, migrations and model visualization in Visual Studio & CLI

issue.body:
Using EF Core power tools for EF core 7, Child entities converted into getter only.

EF 6
public virtual ICollection<x> X { get; set; }
vs 
EF 7
public virtual ICollection<x> X { get; } = new List<x>();

There are few places in our code that need to set this property explicitly.  
 Is there any workround for this?

issue.title: EF Core 7 does not add collection setter

repository.name: EFCorePowerTools
repository.description: Entity Framework Core Power Tools - reverse engineering, migrations and model visualization in Visual Studio & CLI

issue.body:
When I try to use EF Core Power Tools with the option of the first window on the down left "EF Core 7" instead of "EF Core 6", there is no constructor in generated code. There is an option in the advanced settings "Remove default DbContext constructor", which is disabled. I tried to enable it just to check, and no changement. 

But if I choose "EF Core 6", everything act normal. Please notice that my project use Dotnet 7, with every last version packages. My extension is up to date with the last version. I do not know since when I have this problem.

- EF Core version in use: EF Core 7

- Is Handlebars used: no

- Is T4 used: no

- Is .dacpac used: no

- EF Core Power Tools version: 2.5.1277

- Database engine: SQL Server

- Visual Studio version: Visual Studio 2022

If you need any other information I'd be glad to give it to you.
Thanks in advance,

issue.title: EF Core 7 Reverse Engineer Changing ICollection to Read Only

labels.name: duplicate
labels.description: This issue or pull request already exists

repository.name: EFCorePowerTools
repository.description: Entity Framework Core Power Tools - reverse engineering, migrations and model visualization in Visual Studio & CLI

issue.body:
Reverse engineering using EF Core 6 defines my collection like this:

        public virtual ICollection<Programming> Programmings { get; set; }

Selecting EF Core 7, the same collection is defined like this:

    public virtual ICollection<Programming> Programmings { get; } = new List<Programming>();

These collections are in the Equipment model and refer to the Programming model.  The Programming table has a foreign key that references the PK in the Equipment Table.

### Provide steps to reproduce
 
Reverse engineer a table with a foreign key and it will crease a read only list now.

### Provide technical details

EF Core version in use: EF Core 7

Is Handlebars used: no

Is T4 used: no

Is .dacpac used: no

EF Core Power Tools version:  2.5.1277

Database engine: SQL Server

Visual Studio version: Visual Studio 2022

issue.title: How to create setter for navigation properites

labels.name: duplicate
labels.description: This issue or pull request already exists

repository.name: EFCorePowerTools
repository.description: Entity Framework Core Power Tools - reverse engineering, migrations and model visualization in Visual Studio & CLI

issue.body:
Using the latest version of this extension, I noticed that the navigation properties no longer have a setter. Has something changed recently surrounding this? I use the setter extensively in my application.

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/34929316/210394972-7de8fabd-7465-4d90-9f84-466cf8d15974.png)

issue.title: Setter removed from Entity for Child Entities in EF 7

repository.name: EFCorePowerTools
repository.description: Entity Framework Core Power Tools - reverse engineering, migrations and model visualization in Visual Studio & CLI

issue.body:
This piggybacks on [#1582](https://github.com/ErikEJ/EFCorePowerTools/issues/1582) and [#1587](https://github.com/ErikEJ/EFCorePowerTools/issues/1587), of which both are marked closed.   @ErikEJ asked in both threads why would someone want to reassign the navigation property.  In my case we have several places where we sort the collection after it has been returned from the database.

`class.Students = class.Students.OrderBy(s => s.Property).ToList();`

Obviously a trivial example.  The collection of class.Students could have been originally retrieved from the database with or without a sort.  It could have been added to after the original query, etc.  However we need the final collection sorted in place.  Of course there are work arounds like clearing the original collection and adding to it a sorted one, using .Sort(), or customizing the T4 templates. However I'm trying to understand whether our usage goes against best practices?  What is the proper/recommended way of solving this?  There must be a reason why child properties are now read only.  This was not clear from both closed items referenced above.

body: Note from triage: we will change the default back to collections with setters, and take this to Tactics for a 7.0.x patch.

rename.from: Issues with get only collections in EF7
rename.to: Scaffolded collection navigation properties do not have setters

issue.title: Add back setter for scaffolded collection navigations

repository.name: efcore
repository.description: EF Core is a modern object-database mapper for .NET. It supports LINQ queries, change tracking, updates, and schema migrations.

issue.title: [release/7.0] Add back setter for scaffolded collection navigations

repository.name: efcore
repository.description: EF Core is a modern object-database mapper for .NET. It supports LINQ queries, change tracking, updates, and schema migrations.

issue.body:
Port of #30311
Fixes https://github.com/dotnet/efcore/issues/30286

**Description**

The generated code when reverse engineering (scaffolding) from an existing database was changed to drop the setter from collection navigation properties. The setter is not needed for EF use cases, so this made the generated code cleaner. However, it turns out that:

- Like to use the setter to set an entirely new collection, even though it isn't really designed to be used that way
- Some serializers, notably System.Text.Json, ignore properties without setters, even though the property is pre-initialized and so is never null or needs setting.

**Customer impact**

Multiple customers prefer the previously generated code, and, more importantly, System.Text.Json no longer serializes entities correctly. There is a workaround--customize the T4 template to add the setter.

**How found**

Multiple customer reports on 7.0.

**Regression**

Maybe, if you squint. This isn't a runtime code change; it requires the user to generate new code. However, the code generated is different than it used to be.

**Testing**

Tests updated.

**Risk**

Low. No quirk, because this is tooling code. However, the T4 template can be customized to generate whatever the user wants.
